bestBHT.bht: Submission to civil authorities is not just driven by the fear of punishment, but also by a moral obligation and reverence for God's authority. Obedience to the governing powers is not only a practical necessity but also a matter of conscience. While individuals may desire to alter or improve the government, it is essential to recognize that the responsibility for such changes lies beyond their control. Thus, willingly obeying the authorities, both for practical reasons and as an expression of obedience to God, enables us to maintain a clear conscience.

Henry Alford: There is a moral necessity for subjection: one not only of terror, but of conscience.
Because of the divine appointment and mission of the civil officer.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Wherefore ye must needs be subject, not only for wrath—for fear of the magistrate's vengeance.
but also for conscience' sake—from reverence for God's authority.
The inalienable right of all subjects to endeavor to alter or improve the
form of government under which they live is left untouched here.
Albert Barnes: Ye must needs be - It is 'necessary' to be subject to the civil ruler."
Not only for wrath - Not only on account of the 'fear of punishment;' or the fact that wrath will be executed on evil doers.
For conscience' sake - As a matter of conscience, or of 'duty to God,' because 'he' has appointed it, and made it necessary and proper.
John Calvin: We must not only obey, because we cannot with impunity resist the powerful and those armed with authority, as injuries are wont to be borne with which cannot be repelled; but we ought to obey willingly, as conscience through God’s word thus binds us.

Though then the magistrate were disarmed, so that we could with impunity provoke and despise him, yet such a thing ought to be no more attempted than if we were to see punishment suspended over us; for it belongs not to a private individual to take away authority from him whom the Lord has in power set over us.
This whole discourse is concerning civil government; it is therefore to no purpose that they who would exercise dominion over consciences do hence attempt to establish their sacrilegious tyranny.
Philip Schaff: The necessity of obedience rests, not only on grounds of prudence, because of the wrath, but on moral grounds, but also for conscience’ sake; obedience is a religious duty.
The necessity of obedience rests... on moral grounds, but also for conscience’ sake.
Archibald T. Robertson: Ye must needs (αναγκη). "There is necessity," both because of the law and because of conscience, because it is right (Romans 2:15; Romans 9:1).
John Gill: There is a necessity of it, because magistracy is God's ordinance, it is for the good of men; and such that oppose it will severely smart for it."
Subjection to it from Christians should be not only for wrath; through fear of punishment, and for the sake of escaping it; either the wrath of men or of God, in this or the other world.

But also for conscience sake: to keep conscience clear, to exercise a good one void of offence towards God and men; for natural reason, conscience itself, dictates that there ought to be such order among men, that civil government should take place, and ought to be submitted to.
John Wesley: Not only for fear of wrath — That is, punishment from man.
But for conscience' sake — Out of obedience to God.

bhtAttempts.bht: Obedience to civil authority is not just a matter of avoiding punishment, but also a duty to God. Christians are called to submit to the governing authorities not only out of fear of the consequences, but also because it is the right thing to do. The necessity of obedience is rooted in both the law and conscience. It is not for us to decide to overthrow a government, as our goal should be to live peacefully and honor God. Therefore, we must willingly obey the authorities not only to avoid punishment, but out of a clear conscience and as an expression of obedience to God.

Obedience to civil authority is not just about avoiding wrath or punishment, but also about fulfilling a moral obligation and having reverence for God's authority. Christians are called to submit to the governing authorities not only out of fear, but also out of conscience. The necessity of obedience arises from both the law and the innate sense of right and wrong. While there may be a desire for change, it is important to remember that the responsibility for government lies outside the hands of individuals. By obeying for both practical and moral reasons, we can maintain a clear conscience and demonstrate obedience to God.

Submission to civil authorities is not just driven by the fear of punishment, but also by a moral obligation and reverence for God's authority. Obedience to the governing powers is not only a practical necessity but also a matter of conscience. While individuals may desire to alter or improve the government, it is essential to recognize that the responsibility for such changes lies beyond their control. Thus, willingly obeying the authorities, both for practical reasons and as an expression of obedience to God, enables us to maintain a clear conscience.

Obeying civil authorities goes beyond avoiding punishment, it is a moral duty and a reverence for God's authority. Christians are called to submit to the governing powers not only out of fear, but also out of conscience. While individuals may desire to change the government, it is important to remember that the responsibility for such alteration lies outside of their abilities. Thus, willingly obeying the authorities, for practical and moral reasons, enables us to maintain a clear conscience and demonstrate obedience to God.

Obedience to civil authority is not just about avoiding punishment, but also about fulfilling a moral duty and revering God's authority. Christians are called to submit to the governing authorities not only out of fear, but also out of conscience. The necessity of obedience arises from both the law and the innate sense of right and wrong. While there may be a desire for change, it is important to remember that the responsibility for government lies beyond the hands of individuals. Therefore, willingly obeying the authorities out of a clear conscience and as an expression of obedience to God is crucial.
